item.title: 2025 ECAC Esports Spring Showdown | April 4–6
item.description: April 4–6, 2025 | The ECAC Esports Spring Showdown will bring collegiate gaming teams from around the country to the university’s Curtis R. Priem Experimental and Performing Arts Center. The teams will compete in several esports titles, including Rocket League and Overwatch. Bringing in over 125 schools and 800 student teams, the event is reportedly expected to draw in thousands of participants and spectators to Troy.

item.title: Marx, Mars, and Hyrule: Imagining Planetary Futures: Christian P. Haines to Speak on March 28
item.description: Friday, March 28, 4:30 - 6:00 PM, SAGE 3303: What do Marxism, science fiction, and video games have in common? They are all efforts to imagine what it’s like to live in complex planetary ecosystems. In this lecture, Christian P. Haines (Assoc. Prof. of English, Penn State) critically examines fantasies of terraforming as alibis for socioeconomic inequality and political injustice.

item.title: RAF Guide to Sponsored Programs Update
item.description: RAF has updated the RPI Guide to Sponsored Programs to reflect recommendations resulting from an recent internal audit. Updates were made to Part II, Section 2.2 Research Involving Human Subjects, Animals, and Recombinant DNA and Part IV Proposal Approval Process, to clarify that awards will not be set up until all required campus approvals are received. While this Guide contains helpful guidance, nothing within the Guide to Sponsored Programs should be interpreted as formal institute policy.

item.title: Computer Science Colloquia: Clayton Thomas - Explaining Matching Mechanisms to Participants | March 26
item.description: Date: Wednesday, March 26, 2025 11:00 AM - 12:00 PM - Clayton Thomas is a postdoctoral researcher in the Economics and Computation group at Microsoft Research, New England. His work focuses on theoretical computer science and economic design: striving to build systems that perform well under strategic incentives. He completed his PhD in the computer science theory group at Princeton University, where he was awarded the Wallace Memorial Fellowship in Engineering and a Siebel Scholar award.

item.title: How Many Student Support Resources Are You Using?
item.description: Have you explored our comprehensive advising model? Have you taken full advantage of the Center for Career and Professional Development and the Center for Global Communication + Design? What about I-PERSIST and the Student Success Labs? Did you know our median course evaluation for overall instructor rating is above 4/5? There’s so much more to discover! Dive into Standard 3 of RPI’s Self-Study for Middle States Accreditation, a team led by Dr. Sibel Adali and Dr. Tracy Sullivan.

item.title: iEAR Presents! Dr. Theresa Jean Tanenbaum: Transformative Play Lab | March 26 (Virtual Event)
item.description: In this talk, Dr. Theresa Jean Tanenbaum theorizes an emancipatory design practice intended to restore agency and power to those of us who have suffered at the hands of the oppressive normative social order (which is to say, most of us). She illustrates this with a vulnerable autoethnographic discussion of her own experiences of gender transition, and with examples from larp, tabletop roleplaying games, and popular media. Join virtually on 3/26 at 7pm.

item.title: Call for Faculty Reflective Pedagogy Fellows – Applications due April 11th
item.description:
Inquiry-based learning and creativity are key elements toward creating engaged learning. The Gameful and Immersive Learning Teams invite interested faculty to apply to redesign one of their courses (or a course element). Following the successful spring 2024 Innovative Pedagogy Fellows initiative, the Office of Undergraduate Education is capitalizing on this momentum by funding a professional development opportunity for a new cohort of fellows in 2025, the Reflective Pedagogy Fellows.

For information about sharing your news or events, or to change your subscription settings, visit morningmail.rpi.edu.
